change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber changed a qubuts to a shuruq
change.refuni: vav sheva yod hiriq meteg shin shin-dot sheva tav dagesh patah het hataf-patah vav mahapakh vav dagesh
change.changeuni: vav sheva yod hiriq meteg shin shin-dot sheva tav dagesh patah het hataf-patah vav mahapakh vav dagesh

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is וְיִֽשְׁתַּחֲוֻ֤.
The qubuts in the MPK becomes a shuruq dot in the qere.

Dotan notes a later version of this word in this verse, וְיִשְׁתַּחֲוּ֥וּ. Presumably he notes this later word for the unexpected dagesh in its next-to-last vav. This later word is a normal (non-qere) word.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber changed a qubuts to a shuruq
change.refuni: vav patah yod dagesh hiriq meteg shin shin-dot sheva tav dagesh patah het hataf-patah vav dagesh meteg vav dagesh sof-pasuq
change.changeuni: vav patah yod dagesh hiriq meteg shin shin-dot sheva tav dagesh patah het hataf-patah vav dagesh meteg vav dagesh sof-pasuq

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is וַיִּֽשְׁתַּחֲוֻּֽ׃.
The qubuts in the MPK becomes a shuruq dot in the qere.
In WLC, this word has not only an a-note but also a 1-note, presumably because of the unexpected dagesh in the qere’s next-to-last vav.

As a reminder, a WLC 1-note (bracket-1 note) is defined as follows: «BHS has been faithful to ל [...] where there might be a question of the validity of the form and we keep the same form as BHS. (This is similar to the note “]U”, but the latter refers to cases where BHQ has been published and we keep the same form as both BHS and BHQ.)»

Although Dotan has a note about this ketiv/qere, I do not take him to have noted it for the issue at hand: the qubuts-to-shuruq issue. I take him to have noted this ketiv/qere only for the unexpected dagesh in the last vav of the MPK. (This implies a dagesh in the qere’s next-to-last vav.)

I do not think Dotan finds the qubuts-to-shuruq issue notable because he does not note the similar ketiv/qere in gn27:29 words 3 and 4, וישתחו/וְיִֽשְׁתַּחֲו֤וּ. That gn27:29 ketiv/qere is analogous to this one except the next-to-last vav of its qere is free of a dagesh, as expected, and therefore Dotan finds nothing notable about it.

We know that Dotan finds the dagesh notable because he notes gn27:29 word 10, וְיִשְׁתַּחֲוּ֥וּ, a normal (non-qere) word that is analogous to this qere, including having an unexpected dagesh in its next-to-last vav.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber changed a qubuts to a shuruq

The qubuts in the MPK becomes a shuruq dot in the qere.

change.changeuni: vav patah yod dagesh holam alef mem sheva resh munah vav dagesh

The qubuts in the MPK becomes a shuruq dot in the qere.

change.refuni: alef qamats mem sheva resh munah vav dagesh
change.changeuni: alef qamats mem sheva resh munah vav dagesh

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is אָמְרֻ֣.
The qubuts in the MPK becomes a shuruq dot in the qere.
There’s a large, clear dot above the ר; I don’t know what it is supposed to mean, if anything. Surely not a revia!

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber changed a qubuts to a shuruq
change.refuni: vav patah yod sheva dalet patah bet dagesh sheva resh qadma vav dagesh
change.changeuni: vav patah yod sheva dalet patah bet dagesh sheva resh qadma vav dagesh

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is וַיְדַבְּרֻ֨.
The qubuts in the MPK becomes a shuruq dot in the qere.
In WLC, this word has not only an a-note but also a c-note, presumably because WLC has qadma where BHS (in error) has pashta.

As a reminder, a WLC c-note (bracket-c note) is defined as follows: «We read an accent in ל differently from BHS. (This is similar to the note “]C”, but the latter refers to accent differences against BHQ.)»

change.refuni: yod hiriq qof dagesh qamats etnahta het vav dagesh
change.changeuni: yod hiriq qof dagesh qamats etnahta het vav dagesh

The qubuts in the MPK becomes a shuruq dot in the qere.
The dagesh in the qof is way off center, but still legit IMO.

change.changeuni: vav sheva qof hiriq bet dagesh sheva lamed munah vav dagesh

change.changeuni: mem patah he maqaf

The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is מַזֶּ֣ה.

change.changeuni: mem patah he maqaf

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a maqaf
change.refuni: vav sheva he hiriq nun dagesh tsere he maqaf
change.changeuni: vav sheva he hiriq nun dagesh tsere he maqaf

The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is וְהִנֵּה֛וּ.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to bet
change.refuni: bet dagesh sheva ayin tsere merkha bet segol resh
change.changeuni: bet dagesh sheva ayin tsere merkha bet segol resh

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is מְעֵ֥בֶר.
The MPK’s מ does not carry a dagesh for the qere’s ב, for some reason. This is the dual of js24:15.
Dotan notes that strictly speaking, the implied qere is בְעֵ֥בֶר, which leaves the ב unexpectedly free of a dagesh.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber removed a dagesh from mem
change.refuni: mem tsere ayin tsere munah bet segol resh
change.changeuni: mem tsere ayin tsere munah bet segol resh

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is בְּעֵ֥בֶר.
The MPK’s בּ seems to carry a dagesh for the qere’s מ but it is rejected. This is the dual of js22:7.
Dotan notes that strictly speaking, the implied qere is מֵּעֵ֣בֶר, which gives the מ an unexpected dagesh.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber removed a dagesh from mem
change.refuni: mem hiriq mem dagesh sheva lamed holam tipeha final-kaf sheva
change.changeuni: mem hiriq mem dagesh sheva lamed holam tipeha final-kaf sheva

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is בִּמְּלֹ֖ךְ.
The MPK’s בּ seems to carry a dagesh for the qere’s מ but it is rejected. See js24:15, which is similar.
Dotan does not note this case, though he does note js24:15.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to bet
change.refuni: bet dagesh sheva nun tsere munah yod
change.changeuni: bet dagesh sheva nun tsere munah yod

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is אְׄאֵ֣ׄ. (We use אׄ (א with an extraordinary upper dot) to stand in for a blank space.)
The MPK has no letter to carry a dagesh for the qere’s ב. The MPK (points on no letters) is sheva, tsere, and munaḥ.
Why in the margin does it say not only «בני קר ולא כת» but also «בני ק»?
Dotan notes that the next word has an unexpected dagesh in its ב. I.e., it unexpectedly starts with בּ not ב. i.e. בִנְיָמִ֔ן (Vinyamin) would be expected.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to pe
change.refuni: pe dagesh sheva resh qamats meteg tav sof-pasuq
change.changeuni: pe dagesh sheva resh qamats meteg tav sof-pasuq

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is אְׄאָֽׄ׃. (We use אׄ (א with an extraordinary upper dot) to stand in for a blank space.)
The MPK has no letter to carry a dagesh for the qere’s פ. The MPK (points on no letters) is sheva, qamats, and siluq.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to bet
change.refuni: bet dagesh qamats nun qamats yod vav pashta
change.changeuni: bet dagesh qamats nun qamats yod vav pashta

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is אָׄאָׄאׄאׄ֙. (We use אׄ (א with an extraordinary upper dot) to stand in for a blank space.)
The MPK has no letter to carry a dagesh for the qere’s ב. The MPK (points on no letters) is two qamats marks and pashta.
There is also a dot near the pashta, which we ignore. I.e. we assume it is not ink, or in any case not intentional.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to bet
change.refuni: bet dagesh qamats alef hiriq tipeha yod final-mem
change.changeuni: bet dagesh qamats alef hiriq tipeha yod final-mem

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is אָׄאִ֖ׄ. (We use אׄ (א with an extraordinary upper dot) to stand in for a blank space.)
The MPK has no letter to carry a dagesh for the qere’s ב. The MPK (points on no letters) is qamats, ḥiriq, and tipeḥa.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to kaf
change.refuni: kaf dagesh tsere merkha final-nun
change.changeuni: kaf dagesh tsere merkha final-nun

notes.note: The qere atom at issue is part of the qere compound כִּֽי־עַל־כֵּ֥ן.
The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is אֵ֣ׄאׄ. (We use אׄ (א with an extraordinary upper dot) to stand in for a blank space.)
The MPK has no letter to carry a dagesh for the qere’s כ. The MPK (points on no letters) is tsere and merkha.

Dotan notes that strictly speaking, the implied qere and the atom preceding it form the phrase עַל כֵ֥ן. (This implies the more complete phrase כִּֽי־עַל כֵ֥ן.) I do not take him to have noted this for the issue at hand: the lack of a dagesh in the implied qere. I take him to have noted this only because עַל is unexpectedly free of a trailing maqaf.
Note that, contrary to UXLC, עַל is a normal word, i.e. it is not part of a ketiv/qere. It is abnormal only in that it precedes a qere velo ketiv. (UXLC’s encoding is <k>על</k><q>עַל־</q>.)
The manuscript’s lack of a trailing maqaf on עַל is the subject of a currently-pending change proposal, 2024.04.01/2024.01.18-2.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a ḥolam malei dot to vav
change.refuni: tsadi sheva bet qamats alef tipeha vav holam tav
change.changeuni: tsadi sheva bet qamats alef tipeha vav holam tav

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is אְׄאָׄא֖ׄ. (We use אׄ (א with an extraordinary upper dot) to stand in for a blank space.)
The MPK has no letter to carry a ḥolam dot for the qere’s vav. The MPK (points on no letters) is sheva, qamats, and tipeḥa.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a mapiq to he
change.refuni: lamed qamats he dagesh pashta
change.changeuni: lamed qamats he dagesh pashta

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is אָׄאׄ֙. (We use אׄ (א with an extraordinary upper dot) to stand in for a blank space.)
The MPK has no letter to carry a mapiq for the qere’s ה. The MPK (points on no letters) is qamats and pashta.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to vav-qamats
change.refuni: vav patah yod dagesh hiriq vav dagesh qamats lamed sheva dalet darga vav dagesh
change.changeuni: vav patah yod dagesh hiriq vav dagesh qamats lamed sheva dalet darga vav dagesh

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is וַיִּאָׄלְד֧וּ. (We use אׄ (א with an extraordinary upper dot) to stand in for a blank space.)
The MPK has no letter to carry a dagesh for the qere’s וָּ.

Unlike the dagesh, the qamats does not need a letter to carry it; it is allowed to be an orphan. It appears between the ḥiriq and the sheva (of the yod and ל respectively). Unlike the manuscript, our MPK shows that orphan qamats on a אׄ (א with an extraordinary upper dot).

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to bet
change.refuni: bet dagesh hiriq tav sheva het hiriq lamed dagesh patah tipeha tav
change.changeuni: bet dagesh hiriq tav sheva het hiriq lamed dagesh patah tipeha tav

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is אִׄתְחִלַּ֖ת. (We use אׄ (א with an extraordinary upper dot) to stand in for a blank space.)
The MPK has no letter to carry a dagesh for the qere’s ב.

Unlike the dagesh, the ḥiriq does not need a letter to carry it; it is allowed to be an orphan. It appears before the sheva of the initial ת. Unlike the manuscript, our MPK shows that orphan ḥiriq on a אׄ (א with an extraordinary upper dot).

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to yod
change.refuni: vav patah yod dagesh hiriq tav sheva gimel dagesh qamats ayin patah mahapakh shin shin-dot
change.changeuni: vav patah yod dagesh hiriq tav sheva gimel dagesh qamats ayin patah mahapakh shin shin-dot

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is וַאִׄתְגָּעַ֤שׁ. (We use אׄ (א with an extraordinary upper dot) to stand in for a blank space.)
The MPK has no letter to carry a dagesh for the qere’s yod.

Unlike the dagesh, the ḥiriq does not need a letter to carry it; it is allowed to be an orphan. It appears between the pataḥ and the sheva (of the vav and ת respectively). Unlike the manuscript, our MPK shows that orphan ḥiriq on a אׄ (א with an extraordinary upper dot).

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to yod
change.refuni: dalet dagesh qamats nun hiriq yod dagesh tsere munah alef lamed
change.changeuni: dalet dagesh qamats nun hiriq yod dagesh tsere munah alef lamed

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is דָּנִאֵ֣ל.
The MPK has no letter to carry a dagesh for the qere’s yod.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to yod
change.refuni: dalet dagesh qamats nun hiriq yod dagesh tsere munah alef lamed
change.changeuni: dalet dagesh qamats nun hiriq yod dagesh tsere munah alef lamed

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is דָּנִאֵ֣ל.
The MPK has no letter to carry a dagesh for the qere’s yod.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to yod
change.refuni: mem hiriq dalet dagesh qamats meteg nun hiriq yod dagesh tsere etnahta alef lamed
change.changeuni: mem hiriq dalet dagesh qamats meteg nun hiriq yod dagesh tsere etnahta alef lamed

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is מִדָּֽנִאֵֿ֑ל.
The MPK has no letter to carry a dagesh for the qere’s yod.
The rafeh on the א makes it clear that the qere’s yod functions as a consonant not a vowel, i.e. the qere’s syllables are מִ־דָּֽ־נִ־יֵּ֑אל.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a shuruq dot to the initial vav
change.refuni: vav dagesh zayin sheva qof tsere nun hiriq tipeha yod final-mem
change.changeuni: vav dagesh zayin sheva qof tsere nun hiriq tipeha yod final-mem

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is זְקֵנִ֖ים.
The MPK has no letter to carry a shuruq dot for the qere’s vav.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to dalet
change.refuni: he hiriq zayin sheva dalet dagesh sheva mem hiriq nun sheva tav dagesh vav dagesh final-nun pashta
change.changeuni: he hiriq zayin sheva dalet dagesh sheva mem hiriq nun sheva tav dagesh vav dagesh final-nun pashta

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is הִזְאְׄמִנְתּוּן֙. (We use אׄ (א with an extraordinary upper dot) to stand in for a blank space.)
The MPK has no letter to carry a dagesh for the qere’s ד.

Unlike the dagesh, the sheva does not need a letter to carry it; it is allowed to be an orphan. It appears between the sheva and the ḥiriq (of the ז and מ respectively). Unlike the manuscript, our MPK shows that orphan sheva on a אׄ (א with an extraordinary upper dot).

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to tet
change.refuni: bet dagesh patah tet dagesh sheva het holam resh hiriq zaqef-qatan yod final-mem
change.changeuni: bet dagesh patah tet dagesh sheva het holam resh hiriq zaqef-qatan yod final-mem

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is בַּעְפֹלִ֔ים.
The MPK’s ע does not carry a dagesh for the qere’s ט, perhaps because that would be illegal.
Same issue, indeed same word modulo accent, six verses later, in 5:12.
Dotan remarks, in his Foreword to BHL (page xx):

Another example [of a point CEN] is an ʿayin of the ketiv that cannot carry a dagesh that is due in the qere, as in the manuscript in Deut. 28:27 in the [body] text וּבַעְפֹלִים and in the margin ק̇ ובטחרים; in the printed edition a dagesh was added[, yielding] וּבַטְּחֹרִים.
[The terminology CEN (created ex nihilo) is mine, not Dotan’s.]
[In this quote, Dotan omits the accent (zaqef qatan) on the ל of וּבַעְפֹלִים and on the ר of וּבַטְּחֹרִים, perhaps because it is not germane to the topic at hand.]
[Note that dt28:27 is not a-noted in WLC! (*W/B/(PLYM **W./BA/+.:XORI80YM)]

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to tet
change.refuni: bet dagesh patah tet dagesh sheva het holam resh hiriq etnahta yod final-mem
change.changeuni: bet dagesh patah tet dagesh sheva het holam resh hiriq etnahta yod final-mem

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is בַּעְפֹלִ֑ים.
The MPK’s ע does not carry a dagesh for the qere’s ט, perhaps because that would be illegal.
Same issue, indeed same word modulo accent, six verses before, in 5:6.
Dotan remarks, in his Foreword to BHL (page xx):

Another example [of a point CEN] is an ʿayin of the ketiv that cannot carry a dagesh that is due in the qere, as in the manuscript in Deut. 28:27 in the [body] text וּבַעְפֹלִים and in the margin ק̇ ובטחרים; in the printed edition a dagesh was added[, yielding] וּבַטְּחֹרִים.
[The terminology CEN (created ex nihilo) is mine, not Dotan’s.]
[In this quote, Dotan omits the accent (zaqef qatan) on the ל of וּבַעְפֹלִים and on the ר of וּבַטְּחֹרִים, perhaps because it is not germane to the topic at hand.]
[Note that dt28:27 is not a-noted in WLC! (*W/B/(PLYM **W./BA/+.:XORI80YM)]

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to lamed
change.refuni: he qamats alef tsere zaqef-qatan lamed dagesh segol he
change.changeuni: he qamats alef tsere zaqef-qatan lamed dagesh segol he

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is הָאֵ֔הֶה.
The MPK’s ה does not carry a dagesh for the qere’s ל, perhaps because that would be illegal.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a sheva to kaf sofit
change.refuni: shin shin-dot sheva kaf tsere nun qamats etnahta yod hiriq final-kaf sheva
change.changeuni: shin shin-dot sheva kaf tsere nun qamats etnahta yod hiriq final-kaf sheva

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is שְׁכֵנָ֑כִי.
The MPK’s yod does not carry a sheva for the qere’s ך, perhaps because that would be illegal.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to dalet
change.refuni: dalet dagesh hiriq bet sheva yod vav holam nun hiriq tipeha yod final-mem
change.changeuni: dalet dagesh hiriq bet sheva yod vav holam nun hiriq tipeha yod final-mem

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is חִרְייֹונִ֖ים.
The MPK’s ח does not carry a dagesh for the qere’s ד, perhaps because that would be illegal.
the ḥolam malei dot on the qere’s vav comes from the ḥolam (ḥaser?) dot on the yod of the MPK! Instead of being on the yod of the MPK, why isn’t this dot on the vav of the MPK?

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber added a dagesh to tsadi
change.refuni: tav dagesh hiriq tsadi dagesh holam meteg resh sheva nun qamats he sof-pasuq
change.changeuni: tav dagesh hiriq tsadi dagesh holam meteg resh sheva nun qamats he sof-pasuq

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is תִּרֽצְֹנָהֿ׃.
The MPK’s ר does not carry a dagesh for the qere’s צ, perhaps because that would be illegal.
Nor does the MPK’s צ carry a dagesh for the qere’s צ.
More generally, the MPK is a mess, both in terms of neatness and in terms of what marks ended up on what letters.
The below-marks make sense, though one has to sort of squint to see what one expects to see. I.e. the below marks follow the expected order, i.e. the qere order: ḥiriq, siluq, sheva, qamats.

The above-marks is where it gets weird, since the qere צ’s ḥolam ḥaser dot is already present on the צ of the MPK. I would expect the ḥolam ḥaser dot to be on the ר of the MPK, i.e. I would expect it to be in its qere POSITION, not on its qere LETTER. I.e. I would expect תִּרֹֽצְנָה׃.

Avi, in the MAM documentation, reports that the MPK of א follows this pattern more completely: for the two letters at issue in this ketiv/qere, i.e. for the two transposed letters, the pointing is already present on the LETTER it will “land on” in the qere, not in the POSITION it will land on in the qere. That is to say, א-כתיב=תִּרְצֹּֽנָה׃. I.e. to form the pointed qere from the pointed ketiv, all that needs to be done is to transpose the ר and the צ ALONG with their marks!

Dotan’s Appendix A notes, as I have noted above, that the ḥolam ḥaser dot would be expected on (the left side of) the ר of the MPK, whereas it is on (the left side of) the צ. Dotan does not note anything about the creation ex nihilo of the dagesh on the qere’s צ.
A final, unimportant remark is that I’ve put a rafeh above the ה of the MPK but I’m not sure about this; it might belong above the נ.

change.description: Note that while creating the pointed qere, the transcriber changed a ḥataf pataḥ to a pataḥ under ayin
change.refuni: mem hiriq mem dagesh patah ayin patah resh sheva kaf munah vav holam tav
change.changeuni: mem hiriq mem dagesh patah ayin patah resh sheva kaf munah vav holam tav

notes.note: The manuscript’s pointed ketiv (MPK) is מִמַּעֲרְ֣וֹת.
The MPK’s ע has a ḥataf pataḥ where the qere has a pataḥ.

Unexpected ḥataf vowels are a known feature (bug?) of ל. I.e. this is rare but hardly unique. This unexpected ḥataf may well be unrelated to the ketiv/qere differences in this word. If it is unrelated, this should have been a bracket-1 or bracket-U note in WLC, not a bracket-a note.
Breuer notes that א and ק have the expected pataḥ under ע. (א is the Aleppo Codex and ק is the Cairo Codex of The Prophets.)
Dotan notes that strictly speaking, the implied qere is מִמַּעֲרְכ֣וֹת (ḥataf pataḥ under ע).
